reviewText: This set is very cool..first it is about time travel..second the characters and stories pull you in and third the time machine is freaking awesome!Why more people don't buy this collection is a mystery to me...I really got into it..i could watch more...Dr Who fans should check this series out..i believe they would like it..

reviewText: I bought this show on a whim. The price was right and I wanted to fill my basket and qualify for cheaper shipping etc. Also I'm a sucker for anything time travel related.To be fair I wasn't expecting a lot from the series, not least because I'd never heard of it before and it came out in the nineties. And also because there was no second season. So I was pleasantly surprised when it turned out to be quite good.The time travel side of things is a bit hokey. The machine sits in a room and the travellers have to access it, go back into the past and then return just before they reach the present by living through the interval. And some of the rules they came up with were strange to say the least. If you see yourself in the past you'll cause some sort of temporal calamity. If you don't get back to the machine at the exact moment you got in it to go back in the past you'll end up in some sort of infinite loop. All of which leads to one shocking problem the series glossed over. If you're rushing back to the machine to snap back into the right timeline at the same time as your future selves are leaving it to enjoy their time in the past - how do you not run into yourselves?However, putting these questions aside, the series is a strange mixture of light hearted time travel and whodunnit which works surprisingly well. Some of the murders I guessed, some I didn't. The characters are surprisingly believable and likeable, which always helps. And a few of the minor characters produce some amusing moments. There's no blood and gore despite the inevitable murders, and not a lot of violence either.One thing did confuse me for a bit. The feel ofthe show which is distinctly eighties or even seventies, despite being made at the end of the nineties. The lead characters wardrobe - which he never changes is pure eighties. The time machine looks like it's older than the Tardis. And the special effects are quite primitive.Still if you like whodunnits and time travel, you'll probably enjoy this.

reviewText: - Jeff Slade to Holly Turner: "Are you telling me you can build a time machine but you can't cook a cheese soufflé? You've got your priorities all wrong."Here was a late 1990's British police procedural that had a juicy sci-fi element spooned in to dispel all sorts of stodginess. Do you like them drawing room murders? Do you fancy time travel? CRIME TRAVELLER, then, is your perfect beast. Anthony Horowitz, who authored the Alex Rider adventures, created this show and wrote each of the eight quite intricate episodes. He admits to being quite knackered, what with being hampered by the rigid rules of time travel that he himself had imposed and yet each time having to come up with fresh new plot twists. Horowitz claims that the show was cancelled because there was a new BBC head programmer put in place during CRIME TRAVELLER's hiatus, and, during the transition, CRIME TRAVELLER was just never picked up. But I sense a sigh of relief from Horowitz.CRIME TRAVELLER is more cerebral than, say, SEVEN DAYS or VOYAGERS! And yet its hero is just as maverick and bullheaded as Frank Parker and Phineas Bogg. Top cop investigator Jeff Slade (Michael French) was already work pals with the C.I.D.'s science officer Holly Turner (Chlo Annett). Holly is actually a brilliant quantum physicist who only toils in the police department so as to fund her very secret project. Her vanished father had invented a time machine of which upkeep Holly slavishly maintains. But it costs money. The logic hole in that is you'd think she'd be able to come up with a better paying side job than police forensics. When she lets Jeff Slade in on her secret, let the audience strap in for hours of compelling television. It's amusing to see Jeff persistently butt his head against fate. But, undeniably, Slade and Holly form a very good detecting team.Holly is quick to point out the unbendable rules of time travel, and this makes for a fascinating listen for the viewer. We learn that time can't be altered no matter how hard you try (that's you, Jeff). You can only travel to the past, because the future doesn't yet exist. And it's a one-way trip. Once you arrive to the past, you have to live out the intervening hours or days until you catch up to the present. In the bonus feature interview, Horowitz mentions a scrapped storyline in which he has Slade journey to the Victorian era and tangling with Jack the Ripper, but Horowitz couldn't figure a way around the problem of Slade then having to live out more than a century to get back to his timeline.One other conceit that Horowitz develops is that the time travellers must return to Holly's time chamber in the same half-second as when they'd left, lest they be trapped in an endless time loop. To help prevent this Loop of Infinity, Slade or Holly puts on a special watch which is synchronized to the time machine. It alerts them when time is running out. It's a pretty reliable plot device. Several episodes have them barely beating the clock.What we have then are fairly standard murder mysteries enlivened by temporal twists and turns. Horowitz does a bang-up job of keeping the narrative accessible and easy to track.In fact, part of the fun is in seeing how Slade and Holly would explain away certain discrepancies, this mostly having to do with how Slade so brilliantly detects this and that killer's identity. Unsurprisingly, Slade's seemingly miraculous crimesolving draws the suspicion of his no-nonsense commanding officer (Sue Johnston) who in one episode ("Death Minister") deploys an underling to shadow him.Holly has always been reluctant to employ the time machine simply to service Slade's cases. In fact, she addresses her concern that Slade may have become too dependent on time travel. She caustically informs Slade: "My father didn't invent time travel simply to help you with your enquiries. Please, next time, work it out on your own." I really enjoy the banter traded between Michael French and Chlo Annett. There's certainly this simmering sexual undercurrent that I think was this close to being explored when the show got the axe. French is superb and disarming as the unconventional Brit cop. Chlo Annett's Holly Turner benefits from being written as a strong female lead who more than occasionally ends up saving her partner's bacon.All eight episodes are gems, except I have three clear favorites. In "The Revenge of the Chronology Protection Hypothesis," when Slade falls victim to a potentially fatal shooting while working on a case, Holly, who time and again had lectured Slade about the immutability of time, travels back in a frantic attempt to change the past. "The Lottery Experiment" is touted by Horowitz as one of the most favorite television episodes he'd scripted. It features Slade and Holly attempting to face the time paradox problem head on... and hopefully profit from it. With Holly desperately scrimping to purchase parts for the ever deteriorating time machine, Slade concocts a plan to win the Lottery. It's massively fun to see how fate, time and again (heh!), conspires to sabotage his efforts. There's also a very clever parallel plot involving vanished gold bricks. The final episode, "The Broken Crystal," is worth viewing on two fronts. It informs us that it's not only Holly who has a time machine. And, for them romantic sorts, it also introduces a former flame of Holly's, this turn of events not sitting too well with Slade. When a murder investigation convinces Slade that Holly's ex is the culprit, is it truly sound sleuthing at play? Or is it perhaps jealousy? Either way, it lands Slade in hot water. *Sigh* I'll miss Jeff Slade landing in hot water. The equally excellent JONATHAN CREEK replaced CRIME TRAVELLER on BBC's rotation. JONATHAN CREEK boasts a very cool premise in that the lead character is a sleuth and a creative consultant to a stage magician. But the guy doesn't time travel.What I have is the Region 2 version of CRIME TRAVELLER, a complete series set which comes with 4 discs and the following bare bones bonus features:- An interview with writer/creator Anthony Horowitz (00:23:32 minutes)- Episode Synopsis- Returning Cast Bios & Cast Credits for Each Episode- Original Production Trailer
summary: Jeff Slade's initial reaction to the timey-wimey special effects: "Is that it? What did you do? Photocopies?"

reviewText: An English BBC show made in 1997.  It's not bad but It's just not that good.  With limited special effects, which I expected, you would have thought the plots would have been more interesting.  If I were to buy a show it would be Vexed a funny English Detective show.  Now finished it's second season and it is a lot of fun.  This show Crime Travellers only goes back a few hours in time and makes just is blah.  Wish I could have said more but on a positive note the cast is funny.
summary: It's a Crime to waste your time on these travelers.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Crime Traveller is a 1997 BBC TV series which lasted for one season, and produced eight episodes.  The program is centered on the investigation of crimes, utilizing the ability to travel backward in time.  Although the subject matter is generally serious, the approach and tone of the program is often light and adventurous.  While definitely not a farce, Crime Traveller isn't a serious, gritty hard hitting crime drama, as the law enforcement officers featured are hardly shining examples of competence.Holly Turner (Chloe Annett) is a police science officer.  Her father was a famous scientist, who succeeded in building a functional time machine, before mysteriously disappearing.  The strange contraption located in a room in Holly's apartment, is capable of turning back time for a maximum of about a day.Detective Jeff Slade (Michael French) is a cop whose unorthodox and impulsive behavior, and unprofessional attitude, often gets him in trouble with his boss Kate Grisham (Sue Johnson,Waking The Dead).  After a disaster during a stakeout, Slade is in hot water again, until Holly goes back in time and finds information that pulls his behind out of the fire.Holly reveals her secret to her co-worker, which leads to a major change in her life.  She had been experimenting with making short trips into the past, but Slade convinces her to take him into the past with her, to try and solve active criminal cases.Anthony Horowitz (Foyle's War) who created the series, and wrote all eight episodes, succeeds nicely in some areas, while falling short in others, as the stories are inventive, but also have some predictable elements.  Horowitz postulates a set of "rules" regarding time travel, that helps define the parameters of what happens, and makes the unlikely proposition a bit more credible, as the time machine is a contraption constantly on the verge of breaking down.  While not everything fits together convincingly, and the series tries much too hard to be amusing, becoming almost slapstick at times, most of the adventures are entertaining, display some cleverness, and integrate elements related to time travel in interesting ways.You really have to buy into Jeff Slade's fast and loose persona, to enjoy the series.  Slade has a roguish charm, and exhibits flashes of brilliance, but he's also a bit of a bungler, and there are many instances where his headstrongness and overconfidence creates problems, or even results in an injury.  Relying so heavily on journeying into the past, one wonders how Slade managed to solve any cases without the benefit of such an advantage.  Slade's coworkers are not a very competent group, which contributes greatly to he and Holly being able to solve crimes they way they do.Holly is charming and intelligent, but is rather easily manipulated by Slade to continue to use the time machine to solve crimes.  With apparently little to do at work, she and Slade spend an awful lot of time together.  The relationship that develops is warm, but it never quite heats up into the romance that you might expect it to.Time Traveller is lightweight, but mostly engaging fun.  Slade can be annoying and selfish, such as when he uses the time machine without Holly's permission, or when he attempts to use time travel to win a fortune in the lottery, but he and Holly do have pretty good chemistry together.  Although by the later episodes the series appeared to be settling into a groove, it was not renewed and ended its run after only eight episodes.
summary: engaging British crime drama, built around travelling back in time...
Title: N/A
